Comment: Here is an interesting miniature just completed.  It turns out to be a Closed Catalan where black fianchettos the dark-squared bishop.  Without further ado...

My standard response to the symmetrical knight development.  Black's flexibility with his first move allows for a light-square strategy along the lines of the Catalan/QGD, a symmetrical English, Queen's Indian or Kings Indian.

My standard response to the symmetrical knight development.  Black's flexibility with his first move allows for a light-square strategy along the lines of the Catalan/QGD, a symmetrical English, Queen's Indian or Kings Indian.
Black opts for the light-squared strategy.  An ambitious counter which prepares to directly challenge White in the center with ...d5 or ...c5.
I tend towards the light-squard fianchetto in these positions, however, d4 and Nc3 are just as good.
The immediate strike in the center which characterizes the Catalan or Open Reti.
4. d4 is objectively stronger, however, my preparation in the lines involving 4...dc; 5. Qc2 is pretty deep and so I dont mind going into those variations.
An interesting idea, but one which I believe wastes a tempo putting the bishop on the long diagonal, when it has a perfectly good diagonal on the a3-f8 line.
I decide to fix the d-pawn and develop.
Following the plan and maintaining parity in development.
Setting up the standard pawn formation for the closed Catalan.
Setting up the standard pawn formation for the closed Catalan.
Setting up the standard pawn formation for the closed Catalan.
Setting up the standard pawn formation for the closed Catalan.
Here Bd2, and Re1 occurred to me, I decided to protect the pawn this way and maybe fianchetto my own dark-squared bishop.

Taking up residence on the diagonal which now cannot be easily countered.  I believe that this is the major drawback of the fianchetto strategy for black.  The central dark squares are now firmly under white's control.

Taking up residence on the diagonal which now cannot be easily countered.  I believe that this is the major drawback of the fianchetto strategy for black.  The central dark squares are now firmly under white's control.
A logical plan to give scope to the light-squared bishop which finds itself a victim of the pawn formation.
Linking rooks and preparing e4.
10...Ba6 is probably better.
A move on the wings is countered with a move in the center, which has been duly prepared!
I now expected 12...Nxe4 (to limit my influence on d6); 13. Qxe4 Bb7; 14. Rfd1, when White sits better.
I now expected 12...Nxe4 (to limit my influence on d6); 13. Qxe4 Bb7; 14. Rfd1, when White sits better.
Allowing me to drop the knight on d6 with tempo.
Keeping the Queen centralized and preparing to swing the f-rook to d1.  I expected 14...Nh5; 15. Bg5 Ndf6; 16. Ne4 Ng4; 17. Qe2.
